Desirability, form, attendance at,
and frequency of weekly assemblies
Dr. Sherwood Eddy
at the Johns Hopkins University
was discussed yesterday morning at
the open-forum assembly, held in
Latrobe Hall, room 120. Students
at Homewood did not cause a nearriot, as anticipated by local news- To Increase Membership of
papers, but expressed their views
New Orgedlization Is Immediate Objective
rather meekly.

LIBRAR Y FRIENDS MOVE
FOR MORE MEMBERS

Object to Reporters

Serious objections, howeve r,
were raised by many in the closing
ten minutes of the session against
publication by local newspapers of
occurrences similar to that of the
recent wholesale suspension by the
Student Council, and activities at
open-forum assemblies. Censorship
of campus news by the University
Council was suggested. Many declared that reporters should be officially excluded from the weekly
assemblies in order to prevent the
publication of news which might
prove injurious to the public concept of the Hopkins.
Definite Questions Asked

Definite questions were arranged
by Francis Warlow, president of
the Student Council, because, as he
declared, "open-forums in the past
have been rambling affairs at which
nothing has been accomplished."
Asserting that the freshmen have
"high and mighty ideas," Jack
Turnbull, '33, advocated that freshmen be compelled to attend assemblies.
Wants Frosh Regulations

"There's a kick against the school
spirit here," he said yesterday.
"Frosh have high and mighty ideas.
They should be comi5elled to do
something at least—so why not
make them be present at assemblies!"
The main objection to assemblies
is that they are uninteresting, it
was averred by Harold Swartz, '31.
"They should be called only when
an interesting assembly is arranged," Swartz declared.
Advocates Open-Forum
To hold an open-forum semimonthly, it was advocated by Jack
Greenfield, '33. It was pointed out
by him that no compulsion should
be attached to assemblies. Desirability to attend the sessions comes
only with making them voluntary,
he said.
There is no connection between
attending assemblies and _ school
spirit, said Richard Kaufman, '33.
"We are not compelled to attend
classes regularly—'cutting' classes
is permitted here. Then why should
we be compelled to attend assemblies ?" he declared.
Reid Debates Jr., Sr. Attendance

Whether it is desirable to allow
juniors and seniors to be excused
from the weekly sessions was debated by C. L. Reid, '34, who
pleaded for freshman regulations.
For the first half term freshmen
should be taught the college songs
and cheers at compulsory assemblies, declared Talbot Banks, '33.
Subsequently, the sessions should
be held monthly only, he said.
Stern Wants Definite Cuts

Permission to "cut" a definite
number of times was advanced by
Ted Stern, '34, as the only solution to the problem.

Mrs. Hesler D. Richardson, Miss
Grace Turnball, Mrs. Ruth L.
Broscoe and Mrs. Hugh Birckhead.

Wrote Many Books

Despite the fact that he has been
occupied with many duties, the
scheduled "Y" speaker has found
time to do considerable writing. His
most recent books are: "The Challenge of Russia," "Sex and Youth,"
"Religion and Social Justice," and
"New Challenges to Faith." Preceding these were "The Awakening
of India," "With Our Soldiers In
France," and "The New Era of
Asia," among others.

R. K. Witt's Bed, Southern Temperament Is Ruffed,
City College Team

Resolved, That the United States
Join the League of Nations, will be
the subject of the debate between
the Johns Hopkins University
freshman and the Baltimore City
College debating teams, to be held
at the 33rd Street high school, April
10, 3 p. m.
The Hopkins debaters will uphold the affirmative side to the question and will be represented by Saul
Dorfman, Samuel M. Doctofskey,
first and second speakers, and Morton Gutkin, rebuttal.
Six minutes will be allowed the
first two speakers, and eight minutes to the rebuttalists.
City College last year defeated
the Homewood frosh in the annual
forensic battle.

College of Arts and Sciences—injured in leg and nose; a "C" entry

name is unknown to the informant
—shot in the leg; and Harold B.
Yudkin—leg abraised by shot.
Shatter Many Windows

A census taken Tuesday of the
broken windows in the Memorial
Hall, following the complete job
made by the exuberant undergrads
in the recent escapade, revealed 20
missing windows, it was said. As
explained, the snowball "wrecking
crew" had decided to toss snowballs
through all the open windows they
discovered in the dormitory. Of
course, some of the missiles fell
short of the betraying bit of void,
(Continued on page 3, col. 3)

ginia. It reveals vividly the type of
existence the mountain people lead,
and presents realistically a calamitous event in the life of one small
family in particular. The cast includes Miss Margaret Seip, Miss
Mary Alvey, Whiting Farinholt,
Albert Hunt, and Charles Squire.
The program is completed by the
presentation of the comedy "Competition Begins at Home." The
play was written by Miss Julia Cline
and evolves most of its laughs from
the fact that its two leading characters are a married couple and
rival physicians who unfortunately
disagree on the diagnosis of a case.
Miss Cyril Kader, Jesse Robinson,
Miss Dorothy Nathanson, and Miss
Adelaide Lucke compose the cast.
Performance To Begin 8:30

The performance will begin
promptly at 8:30 o'clock. Tickets
are fifty cents apiece and may be
obtained at the Librarian's office,
from members of the casts, or at
the Playshop before the performance begins.

The prize, established in the will
of the late Egbert C. Fuller, wealthy
manufacturer, is limited to $25,000
for each five years and will be given
in memory of his wife, who died of
cancer in 1918.
Mr. Fuller also left a $1,500,000
trust fund in perpetuity for alleviation of suffering from disease and
especially for control of cancer.
His will was probated in court in
Branford, Connecticut, Monday.

M. Cohen, C. Darrell, E. Levi, W.

Miss Stethens Sings
At Midday Musicale
Accompanied at Piano By Mrs. Davis;
Program Is Well Received By
Appreciative Audience

A large audience vigorously applauded the vocal selections offered
by Mrs. Olive Stethens, contralto,
at Tuesday's Midday Musicale in
Levering Hall. She was accompanied by Mrs. Davis at the piano.
Mrs. Stethens' first number was
"Down in the Desert" by Ross, followed by "My Dear Soul," a
Wessex love song, by Sanderson.
The program was climaxed by
"Che Faro Senza Eurydice" from
Gluck's opera "Orfeo." The story
related to this selection concerns the
attempt of Orfeo to have his dead
sweetheart Eurydice restored to him.
The gods consent to his pleadings
on one condition—that he go to the
underworld and play for the girl he
loved. She would follow him, but
he was admonished not to look back
at her until both had passed out of
Hades. Orfeo could not resist the
temptation, and Eurydice was lost
to him forever. The theme running
through the piece expresses Orfeo's
feeling of complete helplessness.
S. S.

Dance For Robinson
Expedition March 28
As a part of the effort to raise
$200 for the benefit of Dr. Robinson's Olynthus archaeological expedition, the Cotillion Board is
sponsoring a formal dance at Levering Hall on Saturday, March 28,
at 9 p. m. The charge will be $1.50
per couple, all profits to be forwarded to Dr. Robinson at Olynthus.

Dr. Sherwood Eddy

was discussed yesterday morning at

New Orgedlization Is Immediate Objective

LIBRAR Y FRIENDS MOVE
FOR MORE MEMBERS

Object to Reporters

Serious objections, howeve r,
were raised by many in the closing
ten minutes of the session against
publication by local newspapers of
occurrences similar to that of the
recent wholesale suspension by the
Student Council, and activities at
open-forum assemblies. Censorship
of campus news by the University
Council was suggested. Many declared that reporters should be officially excluded from the weekly
assemblies in order to prevent the
publication of news which might
prove injurious to the public concept of the Hopkins.
Definite Questions Asked

Definite questions were arranged
by Francis Warlow, president of
the Student Council, because, as he
declared, "open-forums in the past
have been rambling affairs at which
nothing has been accomplished."
Asserting that the freshmen have
"high and mighty ideas," Jack
Turnbull, '33, advocated that freshmen be compelled to attend assemblies.
Wants Frosh Regulations

"There's a kick against the school
spirit here," he said yesterday.
"Frosh have high and mighty ideas.
They should be comi5elled to do
something at least—so why not
make them be present at assemblies!"
The main objection to assemblies
is that they are uninteresting, it
was averred by Harold Swartz, '31.
"They should be called only when
an interesting assembly is arranged," Swartz declared.
Advocates Open-Forum
To hold an open-forum semimonthly, it was advocated by Jack
Greenfield, '33. It was pointed out
by him that no compulsion should
be attached to assemblies. Desirability to attend the sessions comes
only with making them voluntary,
he said.
There is no connection between
attending assemblies and _ school
spirit, said Richard Kaufman, '33.
"We are not compelled to attend
classes regularly—'cutting' classes
is permitted here. Then why should
we be compelled to attend assemblies ?" he declared.
Reid Debates Jr., Sr. Attendance

Whether it is desirable to allow
juniors and seniors to be excused
from the weekly sessions was debated by C. L. Reid, '34, who
pleaded for freshman regulations.
For the first half term freshmen
should be taught the college songs
and cheers at compulsory assemblies, declared Talbot Banks, '33.
Subsequently, the sessions should
be held monthly only, he said.
Stern Wants Definite Cuts

Permission to "cut" a definite
number of times was advanced by
Ted Stern, '34, as the only solution to the problem.

the subject of the debate between

freshman and the Baltimore City

the Homewood frosh in the annual
forensic battle.

Shatter Many Windows

A census taken Tuesday of the
broken windows in the Memorial
Hall, following the complete job
made by the exuberant undergrads
in the recent escapade, revealed 20
missing windows, it was said. As
explained, the snowball "wrecking
crew" had decided to toss snowballs
through all the open windows they
discovered in the dormitory. Of
course, some of the missiles fell
short of the betraying bit of void,

ginia. It reveals vividly the type of
existence the mountain people lead,
and presents realistically a calamitous event in the life of one small
family in particular. The cast includes Miss Margaret Seip, Miss
Mary Alvey, Whiting Farinholt,
Albert Hunt, and Charles Squire.
The program is completed by the
presentation of the comedy "Competition Begins at Home." The
play was written by Miss Julia Cline
and evolves most of its laughs from
the fact that its two leading characters are a married couple and
rival physicians who unfortunately
disagree on the diagnosis of a case.
Miss Cyril Kader, Jesse Robinson,
Miss Dorothy Nathanson, and Miss
Adelaide Lucke compose the cast.
Performance To Begin 8:30

The performance will begin
promptly at 8:30 o'clock. Tickets
are fifty cents apiece and may be
obtained at the Librarian's office,
from members of the casts, or at
the Playshop before the performance begins.

More Volumes Contemplated

Several future volumes in this
series are already contemplated
Volume two, titled Studies in Spenser's Historical Allegory, is written
by Professor Greenlaw, and volume
three, Arthurian Legend in the
Seventeenth Century, is by Roberta
Florence Brinkley, associate professor of English at Goucher College, Professor Brinkley has also
been a Johnston scholar at the Johns
Hopkins University.
The Johns Hopkins Press also
announces a new edition of the
works of Edmund Spenser. Issued
under the supervision of Professor
Greenlaw, of Hopkins; Professor
Osgood, of Princeton University,
and Professor Padelford, of the
University of Washington, in cooperation with a noted group of
specialists, this edition will be the
first variorum edition attempted
since 1805.
Eminent authorities, it was
learned, regard this set of volumes,
which is intended to number eight,
as a great modern contribution to
knowledge of Spenser's masterpieces. The first volume, dealing
with the first book of the Faerie
Queen, is expected to appear sometime in 1931, and will include material that has never before been
gathered together between the covers of one edition. Professor Greenlaw will write the eighth volume of

the rifle-toter and his room-mate,
both chemists, have concocted great
quantities of odoriferous chemicals,
intended to be used instrumentally
in foiling the viligantes here.
But, as matters turned out, no
opportunity was afforded the group
to take Mr. Witt for a ride or permit
him to use his chemicals—for the
rifle-shooter has suddenly disappeared and is said to be in Wilmington, Delaware, now for an indefinite period of recuperation from
the strain of being a hunted man!

Dr. Kemp Malone, Professor of
English philology at the Johns Hopkins University, spoke on "The
Vikings and Their Civilization"
yesterday before the students in the
freshman history class in Remsen
Hall, room 101. Dr. F. C. Lane is
lecturer in this course.
Outlining the origination of the
Vikings, resultant of the quest for
new lands by the peoples in the
Baltic area, Dr. Malone sketched
the social organization and life of
the Vikings—their peasentry, their
meting out of justice and their
literature.

Scheduled for March 27
Entrants Must Sign Up at Locker
Room, Homewood Field, By March
25, Announced

March 27 has been set as the date
for the handicap track and field
meet, to be staged at Homewood
Field. The event is open to all
students in the University. Gold,
silver, and bronze awards will be
given those who "place" in the various events.
Entrants may sign up at the
locker room on the Field daily.
Events to be participated in must
be stated. Entries must be in by
March 25.

Miss Stethens Sings
At Midday Musicale
Accompanied at Piano By Mrs. Davis;
Program Is Well Received By
Appreciative Audience

A large audience vigorously applauded the vocal selections offered
by Mrs. Olive Stethens, contralto,
at Tuesday's Midday Musicale in
Levering Hall. She was accompanied by Mrs. Davis at the piano.
Mrs. Stethens' first number was
"Down in the Desert" by Ross, followed by "My Dear Soul," a
Wessex love song, by Sanderson.
The program was climaxed by
"Che Faro Senza Eurydice" from
Gluck's opera "Orfeo." The story
related to this selection concerns the
attempt of Orfeo to have his dead
sweetheart Eurydice restored to him.
The gods consent to his pleadings
on one condition—that he go to the
underworld and play for the girl he
loved. She would follow him, but
he was admonished not to look back
at her until both had passed out of
Hades. Orfeo could not resist the
temptation, and Eurydice was lost
to him forever. The theme running
through the piece expresses Orfeo's
feeling of complete helplessness.
S. S.

Dance For Robinson
Expedition March 28
As a part of the effort to raise
$200 for the benefit of Dr. Robinson's Olynthus archaeological expedition, the Cotillion Board is
sponsoring a formal dance at Levering Hall on Saturday, March 28,
at 9 p. m. The charge will be $1.50
per couple, all profits to be forwarded to Dr. Robinson at Olynthus.
